explanation:
Explain why each symbol is required to decide if MHD_poll_all violates “A function parameter should not be modified”: 

- mhd_assert
  - mhd_assert is used repeatedly at the top of MHD_poll_all and may be a macro. To prove whether the function modifies its parameters you must inspect the macro/definition to ensure it does not perform assignments to the parameter identifiers (daemon or millisec) or otherwise expand into code that mutates them.

- resume_suspended_connections
  - The result of this call is used to decide whether the function assigns to the parameter millisec (millisec = 0). You need its prototype/definition and semantics (return values) to understand the condition and whether the call itself has any side-effect that could be considered modification of a parameter (or an aliasing effect that would change the interpretation of the assignment).

- MHD_NO
  - The literal/enum/macro MHD_NO is compared against the return of resume_suspended_connections; its value and meaning are needed to determine when the millisec assignment is executed.

- MHD_TEST_ALLOW_SUSPEND_RESUME
  - This options bit is used in the conditional that leads to millisec being set to 0. You must know its definition to evaluate the condition precisely (and to rule out any macro expansion that could modify parameters).

- struct MHD_Daemon (type/definition)
  - The parameter daemon is a pointer to this structure. To decide whether the function illegally modifies a parameter you must confirm whether the function modifies the pointer itself (reassignment) or only the object it points to (allowed). The struct definition also reveals qualifiers (const) on members or the type that could affect interpretation of member updates (daemon->data_already_pending = false etc.).

- get_timeout_millisec_int
  - This helper is called with (daemon, millisec). You need its declaration/definition to confirm it takes millisec by value (no modification of the caller’s parameter) and does not use macros or other constructs that would mutate the local millisec parameter by side-effect.

- MHD_ITC_IS_VALID_
  - This macro/function is used in a conditional accessing daemon->itc. Because macros can expand in surprising ways, inspect its definition to ensure it does not reassign the parameter variable or otherwise hide modifications to daemon/millisec.

- MHD_itc_r_fd_
  - Used to obtain a file descriptor from daemon->itc and passed into p[].fd. Confirm its prototype (does it take daemon or a reference that could cause side-effects?) and ensure it is not a macro that assigns to daemon or millisec.

- MHD_itc_clear_
  - Called when the ITC FD signals. Its definition is required to ensure it does not modify the parameter variables of MHD_poll_all via macro expansion or aliasing. (Functions called from inside MHD_poll_all could mutate the pointed-to object — allowed — but cannot legally reassign the function parameter variable itself; check these definitions to be sure.)

Notes: The core, obvious parameter mutation in this function is the assignment "millisec = 0". To prove a MISRA violation you must (a) confirm that millisec is indeed the formal parameter (not a macro or alias) and (b) ensure no surrounding macro expansions or called symbols implicitly rebind or rename parameters. The symbols above are the minimal set used in conditions or macros that could affect that determination.
